Literature Review: Reprogrammed metabolism is a critical hallmark of colorectal cancer (CRC), characterized by the altered metabolic pathways that support rapid cell proliferation and survival in nutrient-poor environments (Hanahan & Weinberg, 2011). Intestinal stem cells (ISCs), which are the primary cells of origin for CRC, undergo significant metabolic changes during the progression from normal tissue to adenoma and eventually to carcinoma (Bjerknes & Cheng, 2009). These changes are influenced by a complex interplay of genetic alterations, environmental factors, and the tumor microenvironment, including interactions with intestinal epithelial cells, immune cells, stromal cells, and commensal microbes (Clevers, 2013).
